text:
An interesting thread from HN today - <https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=32186203>

Any thoughts on the Data Structures discussed here?

elements.text: An interesting thread from HN today -
Any thoughts on the Data Structures discussed here?

text: A couple people mentioned zippers, which are closely tied to continuations. To be a hair more precise, you can think of a zipper as saving a place in the traversal of a data structure. I think they're important from a PLT perspective.

elements.text: A couple people mentioned zippers, which are closely tied to continuations. To be a hair more precise, you can think of a zipper as saving a place in the traversal of a data structure. I think they're important from a PLT perspective.

text: Wow <@U016VUZGUUQ>, I've never thought of the connection, but it is obvious and beautiful.

elements.text: , I've never thought of the connection, but it is obvious and beautiful.

text: I surely didn't discover it myself. Enter the rabbit hole if you dare. ;) <https://okmij.org/ftp/continuations/zipper.html|https://okmij.org/ftp/continuations/zipper.html>

attachments.text: Generic Zipper as a derivative of a data structure traversal. Zipper File System. Higher traversal derivatives and zippers with several holes.
attachments.title: Final Zipper

elements.text: I surely didn't discover it myself. Enter the rabbit hole if you dare. ;)

text:
Thank you.  Ah ha!  This bit, "We show [delimited continuations] offer a uniform view of many scenarios that arise in systems programming, such as a request for a system service, an event handler for input/output, a snapshot of a process, a file system being read and updated, and a Web page."  Far on my back burner, I have this idea of a "kinetic programming" environment where something like delimited continuations are one of the primary constructs.

Imagine yourself in a VR void.  In the beginning, you just have your own motion of head and hands.  So record a segment of your motion, reify it.  Pick it up, put it over there: a translation in space.  Flatten the time and orientation dimensions: now you have three paths, head, left, and right hand.  Pick out the right hand path.  Map it over the left hand path.  Now you have a surface.  If the right path was an arc and the left path was a loop, the resulting figure could be a ball.  Turn the head path back into motion over time, attach the ball to the head, and now it's bobbing around.  Copy the whole thing and now you have a field of floating orbs.

elements.text:

Imagine yourself in a VR void.  In the beginning, you just have your own motion of head and hands.  So record a segment of your motion, reify it. text: Once I implemented a simple bloom filter. A while back. It was an interesting experience

elements.text: Once I implemented a simple bloom filter. A while back. It was an interesting experience

text: I forgot how exactly it was, but I remember one thing I felt that to be effective most of the time the number of hash functions and size of the bit array has to REALLY big. I may have gotten something wrong. But smaller they are bigger the chances of False Positive.
